Milk foam was not right, texture was not right, temperature was not right, not to mention the foam was almost coming out of the cheap paper cup. And the worse was the staff's attitude towards my disappointment. 

When I try to ask the young Asian man, who seemed to have some experience, to make me a better cup, he took out money from cashier and yielded at me to get out of there, like I was some homeless beggars; especially when I was just expressing my disappointment about the coffee, not money. 

During this little scene, this  just-out-of-high-school chick, or someone who just used expresso machine to make some chemical mixture wanted to join the fight by telling me that my highly-coffee-craving voice volume was "rude", quote, "you were rude when you just came in", when all I said to her was "A-single-cappuccino-please", twice. 

In the end, I had to travel to the other side of town to go to Ritual. 

This is beyond no respect, this incident is an insult! I have read some other reviews on yelp, and it seems that Henry K, the actual owner, also reads about the reviews and gives feedback. I was wondering how the owner can solve this issue.
author: Michelle W.

description: One of the best espressos I've had.  Staff is friendly.  Breakfast foods are just okay.
author: Joel G.

description:
Last week, I stopped by to get some coffee. Something you would expect from a place called "House Of Coffee" after all. Not only did I get coffee, but I got AWESOME coffee. 

Here's the deal, I love coffee.. I practically drink more than plain water. (I know, I know, not really a healthy choice.. ) Anyway, I've been buying beans from the typical bean suppliers here in the city for a while. Four Barrel, Ritual, Sight Glass, Blue Bottle, etc.. And I have to say, those guys are really doing something wrong. They boast their roast, but when you compare their roast to the masters, you quickly see what's going on. They are under roasting their beans. 

I recently did a taste test, we brewed up some Four Barrel "Friendo Blendo", Ritual "El Angel", Sight Glass "Owls Howell", and Blue Bottle "Steppes", and compared them to the "Thailand AA" beans from House of Coffee. 

All of the coffees were made using the same methods. I used an Aero Press, with the exact same amount of grinds from the same grinder and setting and the same temperature water. (Roughly 195 degrees)

The results were astounding! 

Four Barrel was very "bright" and sour.
Ritual was exactly the same.
Sight Glass was slightly less so and a little sweet lacked bite.
Blue Bottle was bright, but  a bit sweet and lacked that "espresso" bite. 

House of Coffee Thailand AA was spectacular. It was exactly what I would expect from a perfectly roasted bean. 

One of the reasons I believe the others beans are under roaster is that a. if you look at them, they are nearly tan in color.. Coffee beans need to be dark brown.
The other reason is that when you use a hand grinder to grind your beans, you really get a "feel" for the roast. The under roasts lack the oils and the beans are harder, so the grinder has to work harder. Whereas a well roasted bean lubricates the grinder as its going through, making the grinding process go a lot quicker and smoother. Yielding grinds that haven't been re-heated due to friction in the grinder.

So, if you're looking for a master roaster who knows his beans and coffee, go to House of Coffee.. If you are looking for over priced hipster coffee, go with the others.
author: Mark C.

description:
Went there to get a latte - the prices seem fair and on par with with you get at Starbucks. The difference is quite obvious. The they roast their own beans in-house - so what you taste here, I assure you, will set this place apart from everywhere else. Ordering and paying - a bit confusing, but the staff is nice enough to help. 

I'll be dropping by soon. :)
author: Jane E.

description:
House of Coffee is where I had my first sip of this magical drink as a teenager. Before Starbucks made it to Noreiga, House of Coffee was probably the ONLY coffee place on Noriega. 

The shop always lets out this wonderful aroma you can smell a block away, so it's understandable why there's ALWAYS customers in the store getting coffee. On Sunday mornings, there's always at least 4 or 5 car double parked outside as the customers run in for the morning cup of Joe. 

Although House of Coffee is a little mom and pop shop, they've definitely done some improvements over the years to make the store not look not too shabby. The owner hand roasts all the coffee in the back room every day in small batches so you know that this is a store that really puts effort and stands behind their products. Whenever I'm back at home and I'm craving a cup of Joe, I ALWAYS choose House of Coffee over Starbucks even though Starbucks is more convenient for me.
author: Jess s.

description:
Truth in advertising here - It's all coffee baby!

Fresh roasted beans on site can be such a delicious rarity these days. Sometimes you have to travel and extra few miles for that "fresh" cup. A big bonus is the quality of beans they also sell. The prices are decent on a few brands that can be hard to find.

Seating and atmosphere is a little bit lacking in some senses. But I view this store as more of a coffee purist location. It is all about the bean. With a zip, a kick, and a fresh bag of beans I was on my way and happy to attack the day!
author: Nick B.

description: Tiny shop with a nice ambiance. There are only a few seats so I would imagine sitting down and doing some work is a hit and miss affair at times. Fortunately I was lucky. The coffee was very good as was the pastry. The shop also has a nice assortment of other items for sale. Before leaving I couldn't help buying some butter cookies. It's always good to have some of those at home.
author: Gerry M.

description:
I stopped in this place while I was waiting to get my oil changed down the street. Maybe, I'm not as impressed with it as a lot of others seem to be since I don't live in the area and wouldn't seek this place out, but it was still OK. 

I just had a small cup of coffee and a chocolate chip cookie. The coffee was fine, but didn't really taste all that fresh. It wasn't a big deal though since I came at ten after five and they close at six, so I wouldn't expect fresh coffee (I used to be a barista and I KNOW that when you're that close to closing you're not making fresh coffee). The cookie was pretty good as well. You can tell it wasn't fresh baked since it was wrapped in plastic (as were the muffins and croissants), but like I said it still tasted good. 

They don't have a lot of fancy shmancy drinks on the menu; just your basic coffee and espresso based drinks, but I think that's the point. The guy who runs it seems to be very passionate about all things coffee. For such a tiny place they carry a lot of coffee makers, presses, tumblers, etc., as well as teas, jams, and those sort of things. 

There isn't a lot of seating (a couple tables inside and a couple tables outside), and I thought the set up was a little funky (there appeared to be a large storage room in the back and the "office" was set up out front for all the customers to see). Since I don't live close by, this isn't the type of coffee shop I'd seek out some lazy weekend morning, but if I ever come back to get my oil changed at the 76 station down the street, I'd stop back in.
author: George A.

description: Excellent coffee; the coolest roasting machine, which infuses the air with the coffee smell a block away (at about 9-10 am by the owner).
author: Veronica D.

description:
This place is whack. I'd heard good things about it from my uncle and so I finally decided to try it out. At first glance it's quite nice- it has a homey feel to it, and coffee beans are everywhere. now, when I say "homey," it's a euphemism for CRAMPED. I stood to the side and found that I was in everyone's way, and moved around several times because it was uncomfortable because people kept squeezing by me. 

Regardless, the coffee is the most important part of the establishment, and to be honest, it was disappointing. Tasted like run-of-the-mill burnt burnt burnt coffee. The flavor was overbearing - I haven't added milk or sugar to my coffee in a really long time but it was needed for this coffee. Other than that, it was a weak-bodied coffee hiding behind a mask of bitterness and acidity. They have beans here but I didn't bother. Standard pricing I guess, and they sell Jamaican Blue Mountain here but I wouldn't buy it personally.
author: Shelby C.

description: I have been drinking Henry's coffee for going on 30 yrs...cant say i have had better.
author: Rick T.

description: Who knew there is a coffee shop in the sunset who roasts their own beans?!  Now that the excitement is over, the coffee is average in my opinion...actually its darker than I like.  Would I go back?  Probably if I'm in the area.  Next time I might even hang with the old asian men sitting outside sipping coffee and tea, and smoking cigarettes.
author: Dean W.

description:
Bad customer service. 

I'm not exaggerating, but the moment I walked inside, I swear the barista was throwing daggers my way. I immediately noticed an unfriendly and unwelcome vibe here. Total negative. If you want to attract customers, i'd probably recommend hiring a friendlier staff. Just totally ruined the experience of a small coffee shop. Oh yeah, and the drinks are average. It's something you can find anywhere, so i'd probably go somewhere else where it tastes the same, but you don't get the death stare the moment you walk inside the establishment.
author: Lauren L.

description:
In a part of the Sunset that seems to have eluded Starbucks and Peets, House of Coffee stands as a hidden gem. The beans are freshly roasted on site. Their Americanos, lattes, and mochas contain a good portion of espresso (unlike the watered-down Americanos from Starbucks). 

They have a great selection of gourmet coffee beans here as well. There is Pure Kona (distinguished from Kona Blend, which contains only 10% actual Kona), and Jamaican Blue Mountain.

Every sip of their coffee was pleasurable.
author: Willk W.

description:
Burnt undrinkable swill

i tossed it out after 2 sips

sugar cookie tasted weird
author: erik H.

description:
$2 for a medium cup of coffee. Hopefully it's good... It was! I drink my coffee black with nothing else in it and it was actually one of the better cups of coffee I have had recently. Plenty of seating but it was pretty packed considering it was 11:30 AM on a Friday morning. 

Not sure if they have wi-fi but there is a cute Asian cashier! =)
author: Wilson T.

description:
The FLIMSY: Coffee overflow made the cardboard cupholder soggy and a cup of espresso fell thru the bottom, splashing the darkness onto my floormats. 

Dabbing 98 degree coffee from my floormats made me feel like an emergency medical tech trying to stop the bleeding from a wounded roadside deer.

No complaints about the coffee.
author: Robin H.

description: Great coffee, great staff, great service.  All around greatness. Wonderful little establishment. Best coffee I've encountered within the sunset.
author: Alvin S.

description:
You have to be kidding me.

If I was blindfolded, and someone handed me the double iced mocha I just ordered and told me to guess what was in it, I would have ventured, "Ice, milk, Nesquick, and a hint of Ovaltine." 

I would be absolutely shocked to discover that there was even a single drop of coffee present in this abomination. Perhaps they are taking a homeopathic approach to coffee, where less active ingredient supposedly increases efficacy?

I was so incredulous after my first couple sips that I decided to drink the whole thing, just in case the straw came full of syrup or something. No luck. It only got worse. 

BY FAR the worst iced mocha I have ever had, and I've had a lot of them. Maybe they forgot to add the espresso, but even still, the flavoring was nasty.
author: Lucas P.

description:
4 stars. They have tons of variety (and Blue Mountain Jamaican - which is a bit pricey $25 a lb), decent prices - I got a latte (iced) and paid $3 (for a regular) however, they require a $5 minimum for credit cards (which sucks) so I had to buy a blueberry muffin, which I was not really big on (it was O.K.).

I give the latte itself 4 stars. The service was good too. They gave me my latte with a faulty lid, so it spilled on me, the younger guy behind the counter came over to my table when I asked if the lid to go worked on the plastic cups, and took it from me, and put it into a new cup with a lid that actually stayed on and did not leak. I also had to ask for a frequest buyer card "was not offered" so that was another thing that kept me from giving them 5 stars.
author: Bella B.

description:
They have the best chai here, like for realsies. 

I've always had good experiences here, the staff is so friendly and they seem to have a good amount of regulars that come by often. I have to admit not a huge fan of the espresso drinks but they also have a good stock of loose leaf teas here. You can request it hot or iced. The lychee iced tea is delicious! And they also roast their own beans here, in which I find it kind of rare here in the city that is taken over by corporate coffeehouses. 

The only real complaint I have really is that when I ordered my iced tea I asked if there was any way for me to sweeten it, possibly with a liquid sugar. The girl gave me this weird look and said no. And that there was regular sugar at the condiment bar. I guess I had asked something that's never been asked before? I guess I'm the weirdo. But seriously not a big deal.
Overall,
Chais. Yay. 
Espresso drinks. Meh.
author: Tutti C.

description: You can smell pure roasted coffee just standing outside of the store on the sidewalk. It envelops you and drags you in to buy their coffee. It's homey and doesn't have that crowded Starbucks vibe. Plus, there's not a bunch of scattered tables and chairs to allow you to sit anyways. The coffee is good! Unless you're ordering a fancy schmancy double whip mocha whatever drink, you fill up your own large cup of coffee and start your day with a real cup of coffee.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I have been here twice. Both times I went just for the coffee of the day. The first time I had the Colombian, it was strong and worth my $1.75. I tried to show the cashier the discount on Yelp on my iPhone, but they didn't honor it. She said that I had to print it out. So that's what I did the next time.

The second time I went, I had the Jack's Blend, or whatever it's called. It was BLEH... Tasted watered down. Didn't feel the caffeine at all. I gave the printed out coupon to the cashier and he said that it was only for the beans so I couldn't use the coupon. I told him that the coupon specifically said on any purchase, which means I should be able to use it on regular coffee. He said, "Buy some beans." Then I proceeded to tell him that the last time I came, they told me that I could use it if I printed it out. Then he reluctantly gave me the $1 discount. Call me cheap or whatever, but a $1 discount is a lot on a coffee that cost $1.75. It's more than half!

Anyways, probably wouldn't come here unless I'm in the area. Even then, I would probably go to Safeway for some Starbucks coffee.
author: Carrie Y.

description: If you love great coffee, you will love this place. Being there when Henry is roasting is a real treat. Watching his level of concentration ensuring his customers get the finest roasts possible is proof enough that he runs a great house.
author: Art R.

description:
House of Coffee is a true gem and if you've never been there you are really missing out. I am a huge coffee snub and I take my coffee very serious and this place really know how to make coffee. :) More importantly Henry really knows how to pick and roast his beans.  The fact that he roasts his coffee 6 days a week, makes for some seriously fresh beans.  But eve more important than that, Henry really listens to his customers and the end result is I am always in coffee heaven.

The other day I came in wanting some light roasted beans, so Henry suggested Columbian, but I was in the mood for less lively African beans and he suggested Abyssinian Harrar, but because I like my coffee less lively he put in an ounce of french. The end result was perfection! 

If you are really particular about your beans, come and talk to Henry. I bet he will make you a personal blend that will hit just the right spot!
author: Julia V.

description:
Damn!  The house coffee is amazing.  At first, I thought a $1.75 for a small cup is a bit pricey, but after scorching my tongue and throat drinking that first gulp, I became a fan.

I'm still drinking this bitch cold, that's how good this coffee is!  

If you live near Noriega, hit this spot up!  Too bad I live so far (I reside in Daly City).
author: Doug F.

description: Mmm mmm Chai! Been attempting to lay off the coffee for now since I've been getting some jitters. Was brought here by my boyfriend who said I should try the Chai Latte. It was definitely made the way that I like, spicy and full of tea flavor. The shop is cute with some seating inside. They sell an assortment of brewing items for tea and coffee. Good stop on a foggy afternoon!
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: Coffee is excellent, although there are few choices for baked goods. The environment is quiet and restful. I go here on Sunday afternoons to work on my studies and find it relaxing. They offer free wifi.
author: Mike A.

description:
If you're looking for a nice little local place to grab a great cup of coffee, then House of Coffee is your place! 

I've always passed by the shop, but never tried it until recently, and I'm definitely a fan now! The service is excellent, everyone is super nice and welcoming. 

My favorites are the Mochas (by Becky for sure!) and the hot chocolate! 

So if you like good coffee and supporting local businesses, you definitely want to check this place out!
author: Sharon L.

description: It's a quaint little local coffee shop that sells coffee just as it is. Don't expect fancy latte art or anything, but do expect some good quality coffee. My mother got a jasmine latte, which was just really a fancy way of saying jasmine milk tea, and it was delicious. The jasmine tea was very aromatic, and the drink definitely tasted way better than what you could have gotten at a boba shop for the same price. I got a kona blended coffee slushie/frappcino drink thing, and it was delicious as well. Out of the two drinks, I definitely preferred the jasmine latte though.
author: Alice L.

description: I've been here a few times. Service is always good. Today I decided to try a Jasmine Latte. It was Very Very good! Would keep coming here just for that! Yummm!
author: Taylor W.

description: Every time I visit my daughter in the Sunset, House of Coffee is a must stop for me!  I love supporting small businesses and thankfully, this is a perfect place to support.  All of the staff are friendly, knowledgeable, and down to earth (not pretentious by any mean!). I love their soy & chai lattes!  I always pick up a pound or two of coffee when there- one for me and one for a friend.  And the pistachios (that Henry roasts there just like the coffee beans) are amazing!
author: Alexandra W.

description: I'm not a coffee snob but I'll just say what I noticed when I dropped in for some quick coffee. It's a small shop but gosh it smells so good. The service is quick and I asked the barista for something light (I ended up ordering a cafe au lait). He wasn't too certain about what I wanted but I thought it was really nice that he asked me to try what he made to see if it was to my liking-- and hence the 4 stars for being accommodating.
author: Jolene L.

description:
This place is really good.

 I always get the Ethiopian fancy. When I first started buying coffee I tried a lot of different varieties. They have like fifty. But now I know which one is my favorite. 

I recommend you do the same. Just try them one at a time until you find which one is right for you. You can even ask Henry for tips in getting your coffee right !

Henry has a roaster in the place, and if you are lucky, you might show up when he's roasting. It smells great! 

If you like coffee, this is the place!
author: Tasos P.

description: Good cap. 2 demerits for just ok barista skills and extra dark roast and 1 merit for  roasting there own coffee. A Peets drinker would enjoy the dark roast more then me. Staff friendly enough.
author: R L.

description: This place is around the corner from my brother's home -- so when he visits LA, he always brings me a fresh roasted bag of their Mocha Java Blend.  I use a burr grinder to process these beans to make delicious coffee at home - it's the best present that keeps giving for days.
author: T Z.

description:
So I'm not really a coffee drinker but my friends wanted to meet here to get our day started and boy am I glad they did.  I had a white chocolate mocha and it was very tasty.  Not too sweet and the coffee flavor was just right for me.  All the baristas were extremely friendly and helpful.  

Because my friends run on asian time, we spent quite some time hanging out here.  The most unique part of this place was the coffee roasting.  I'm not sure if they do it every day but that saturday, every so often, the small joint would fill up with smoke from the roasting of the coffee beans.  It was definitely an experience.  

One other thing that I noticed was that most of the customers were regulars.  It seemed as if the baristas knew almost every single person that entered.
author: Eddie L.

description: My fav little local coffee shop. Quick service to house coffee and almost always you can find Henry roasting his own beans right in the store. It's a complex process and a fancy old machine but he produces good quality coffee perfect for all the foggy days.
author: Jessica M.

description: Henry knows his coffee bean and roasts the coffee  on site, so the aroma alone is worth a visit.  Try the Henry's Blend--I think it is the best local blend.
author: marie c.

description:
I grew up in this neighborhood and lived just 2 blocks away from this little cafe. I always remember walking by this place as a kid with my grandparents and how much I loved how you could smell the delicious aroma of the roasted coffee even when you were a block away. I couldn't wait to grow up and be able to drink coffee! 

I also remember when I was in 4th grade and we were all reading The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe. One of my classmate's mom surprised the entire class by giving each kid a Turkish Delight that she apparently got from House of Coffee. It was one of the best and most memorable things I ate as a little guy.

And now, as an adult... I still can't help but get drawn in by the intoxicating scent of the coffee and feel complete nostalgia. Have a cup if you're in the area... it's wonderful.
author: jen c.

description:
This is where I buy my coffee beans.

i love this place, nice people and great coffee.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Everybody here rocks. I LOVE THEIR COFFEE. The coffee is fabulous, off top.

I'm glad my dad finds good coffee places. I know this place is his favorite.

When I used to go to Lincoln, I'd come by here every now & then when I was feeling tired. One day, my dad was sitting there with a client or friend, and I went to him and snatched his coffee. :) Hehe. Saved myself a couple dollars, but it was a pretty big coffee!

Black coffee. Yummmm.
author: Erica A.

description:
Henry is right there roasting coffee whenever you walk in. This guy is an old-world roaster and in a world of chain coffeeshops you should support places like this in neighborhoods like this. 

Tasty coffee too.  Finca blend was terrific in my Aeropress.

Does this need to be your favorite coffee in the world to give it 5 stars? No. But it's darn fine coffee and the service I got was quite nice. If you don't support this guy all you'll have left is $8 sightglass-pourover-hipsterjuice or mass-produced Starbucks. A local nonchain option is an essential part of our city's coffee ecosystem.
author: Al M.

description:
I love love love their coffee here. Their coffee taste so much better and more fresh than your typical Starbucks or Tully's (even better than blue bottle, in my opinion). It is also strong, keeping me alert during my early morning shifts. They also have a HUGE classic roaster, which is a great asset to their shop. 

Best local coffee shop in the sunset.
author: Denise W.

description: Absolutely amazing! I have been getting Henry's coffee since I moved to San Francisco 3 years ago. Now I also shop there before Christmas and sent their coffee to my family and friends. It's just so delicious that everyone who ever tasted it wants it!!! And I love the aroma that spreads all over my car on my way back home from visiting House of Coffee!
author: Kasia G.

description: This place was one of the few places open on Labor Day, so my boyfriend and I went there for breakfast on our way to a long hike. It was decent coffee and bagel sandwiches. Not something I would write home about, but just fine for a Monday morning of limited food options.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Disclaimer: I've only been here once

But that one time was pretty nice. There really is very little room to stay and drink, but for me that wasn't an issue. I got a cappucino (std fare for me) and it wasn't anything spectacular. It's not an issue with how they made it, which was a-ok, but just a personal preference for less flavor... I prefer something a bit smoother that blends with the steamed milk more. I felt like the espresso overpowered the milk a bit. Still, this is just a preference thing, and if you're into the particular flavor of their espresso I think you'd be perfectly happy with your cappucino.

But what I really want to give them props for is their coffee. Having never been here before I told the woman at the cash register that I wasn't sure what I wanted but I wanted something that wasn't too rich, but still around a medium roast. She suggested Henry's blend, which she said was a blend of medium and dark roast. This sounded like it would be too dark, but I took her advice and purchased half a pound.

Had them grind for French Press, and drank a couple of cups via that method........WOW....supremely smooth, but still a nice flavor. Every aspect of the flavor is great. I feel like I could drink it all day every day!

Future reviews as I try more roasts!!
author: Josh S.

description: They have a really good supply of brewing equipment for sale, coffee though is just ok.  I have bought their beans a few times.
author: Demanding T.

description:
The latte that I ordered from here was delicious.  I have also never seen an actual coffee roasting machine so that was amazing. If I drank coffee more I would have definitely picked up a bag from here. I can only imagine how great a freshly roasted coffee bean would taste. 

I would say that this is not really a place you come to sit and chat with your friends. There were only a few seats inside. If you want a good cup of coffee/latte's on the go, it seems like it would be perfect!
author: Kim T.

description: Henry and his son Hrag are the real deal. Don't like a blend? Tell them what you didn't like about it and they'll work on customizing a blend for you. Become a regular customer and they'll keep a card in their Rolodex of what you like, then you can call ahead and they'll fresh roast it for you. Want to learn more about coffee or tea? Ask them. You'll become an expert in no time!
author: Scott R.

description: My local coffee shop is a hidden gem that is never very busy.  I come for the delicious lattes as well as expresso beans they'll grind for you if you like and loose leaf tea.  I like this small coffee joint atmosphere. The staff are very friendly and seem to know most people by first name.
author: Allison H.

description: Coffee and bagel very  good. When you roast the coffee in store it's great , but it would be good to have more air vent . Staff not bad depending on the time you go.
author: Jeff T.

description:
Cute place, great selection of all things coffee, coffee makers, filters, teas, and yummy European goodies. 
But... they definitely need a thermometer for their drinks. Even their tea is burned because the water is too hot. I've been there so many times, and I really want to enjoy them, but damn... burn my mouth every time! And when I ask them to make it a lil cooler, it came out warm. Now, yes, I am a coffee snob, but nothing beats a really good cup of joe, or cappuccino, or latte. 

I'd give it higher stars, as soon as they get a thermometer!
author: T O.

description:
My new favorite coffee joint in my hood! 

I've been to house of coffee a few times for their drip coffee as it was super close to my old house.  As of recent - I've discovered my inner beast loves a medium Americano! Yum yum! I have to stop in at least once on the weekends to get my fix!
author: Julie F.

description: Awesome service!!! Great loose leaf teas. They also have a lot of coffee paraphernalia.
author: Kathy L.

description: Good coffee, very good espresso and enough coffee geek gadgets to keeop you busy while you wait for them to fix you up something good. They even have those "buy 12 get one free" cards that just a select few coffee shops in San Francisco have. Props for having the roaster active so we customers can watch and major props for being one of the few great coffee shops in the outer sunset.
author: Heshy F.

description: Coffee - Love!!!! Bella Finca beans are my favorite! Rich and full tasting beans without that overly roasted flavor. It's a dark roast.  My husband and I pick up his office stash here every few weeks. We have a stash at home as well. We drink it through drip or French press.... Amazing! Best roaster in SF. Thanks Henry!
author: Jessica W.

description:
BEST CUP OF COFFEE I'VE EVER TASTED. 

I've NEVER been disappointed by this place. When you drink their cup of coffee, all you get is flavor. Especially when the coffee of the day is of a dark roast. Even when it's not dark roast, the coffee is still pretty strong. I still can't drink it black so I just put a minimal amount of milk and sugar. Only the coffee from here can keep me wired for a good portion of the day unlike Starbucks coffee or coffee from any other store. It's also pretty cool to be able to see the beans being roasted right in front of your eyes and the store suddenly fills up with this heavenly coffee aroma which you can smell all the way down the street as well.

The customer service is also pretty amazing. They usually sell these cookies from the Nutty Cookie company and they had the best Lemon Butter cookie I've ever tasted. One day I went back for the Lemon Butter Cookie but it was out of stock. I went back again and they still didn't have it so the owner Henry promised to order it and have it stock for me the next time.  To my amazement, everytime I've been back there, the Lemon Butter cookie have been fully stocked. Talk about going out of your way to please your customers.

If you don't drink coffee or want something different, I'd recommend trying the loose leaf teas. I believe the owner prepares them himself and they are definitely fully packed with flavor not to mention the wide selection. 

If you want to prepare coffee and tea at home, there are a bunch of great gadgets sold at the store at reasonable prices. Watch out for the sales. That's how I got my thermo tumbler for cheap.

If you haven't been to this coffee house run by a 4th generation coffee roaster who has mastered the art and beauty of great tasting coffee, I'd recommend you pay a visit soon!
author: Dorothy W.

description:
Love House of Coffee, I drink coffee and iced coffee, none of the crazy other drinks like mochas,etc. and can say I have never been disappointed by their cup o' joe. 
I love that they are always friendly, the "mom and pop" coffee shops are really the best in the city. I also love walking in while they have the giant roaster going, it's a very cute little shop with great coffee and friendly faces, it always help my weekends feel a little brighter in the supremely foggy neighborhood
author: Jennifer T.

description: My husband claims House of Coffee is THE best in SF.  You'll catch him here on a daily basis.  Due to my hectic work schedule I can only make it on weekends.  Their beans are hand roasted daily and you can smell the aroma from blocks away.   So skip the Starbucks & Blue Bottle and head on over today.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Great selection of coffee. Knowledgeable staff. A few days a week, it smells like roasted coffee too, which is always a plus.

Though I am a regular, auto-drip kind of person, they do have a number of different coffee-making apparatuses if you are a hardcore coffee person. 

I think the prices are very good and the products (at least what I get) are consistently good. Even the decaf-haters in my family have been (somewhat) converted over by the House of Coffee Decaf.
author: Audrey H.

description:
I have been coming to Henry's House of Coffee for many years now. I love the fact that Henry roasts his own beans with passion always checking the beans to roast to perfection from my experience. 
The customer service has always been so wonderful to me. They were always so willing to help me with my choice of beans when I am looking for something new to taste. They ask me questions, show me a variety of beans, let me smell them, and tell me about the flavors I will experience as well. They also do this with the many teas they have as well. 
This is the only place I will buy my coffee. I used to go to Starbuck's and Peet's, but found that because they roast their coffee beans in mass production and can not and do not achieve the quality like Henry's. I just found out that when I am unable to go to Henry's for my coffee I can order it for delivery at a cost of $5.00. This is so worth it for me on those days I can't make it there. Thank you Henry for sharing San Franc your love and passion of coffee
author: Lisa C.

description:
Roasts and grinds his own coffee beans daily. Immaculate, well-lighted establishment with a gorgeous interior. Don't remember if there's a place to sit down. Owner and workers are very polite -- most are pretty friendly. The owner loves what he's doing and he reminds me of the Italian family restaurants where the owner comes out and stops by every table to chat. You get that feeling, though he does seem to be a bit busy.  House of Coffee is known among other Sunset district coffee shops for its good coffee. I guess proof of that some of these shops buy their coffee here! 

I admit to liking the coffee a wee bit more at a place on 24th Ave and Taraval but because all of the above and because walking into the House Of Coffee usually seems like such a cheery experience I'll have to give it 5 stars. Pricey. And so are refills.
author: Robert F.

description: The coffee here is pretty weak, but the worst part of it was that there was coffee grounds settled at the bottom of my cup. The only reason why I'm giving this place 3 stars instead of 2 stars is for their variety of other coffee accessories. If I was ever in need for some supplies I would check this place out again, but other than that I don't think I'll come back for the coffee.
author: Nick L.

description: Good coffee (pour yourself), nice staff, and yummy breakfast sandwiches (the #3 is tasty!). It always smells delicious in there as they roast their own beans. They also have some retail items for sale (coffee/tea mugs, french presses, jams, etc) A great place to stop into.
author: Meg L.

description: I always smell the nice scent of coffee every time I pass by this place so I always wanted to try this place . I finally had a chance to do so a couple weeks ago . I had their mocha which was really good . One of the best mochas I ever had . The mocha was very well-balanced with coffee and cocoa . I liked how it wasn't too sweet and how you can still taste the coffee . The taste of coffee was definitely there ... it was nice and strong but not too bitter . I liked how their mocha wasn't watered-down or too bitter like how a lot of other places make it . They also sell interesting coffee machines and many other things in this shop .
author: Eileen L.

description: Best coffee in the Outer Sunset!  Fresh roasted beans and nice snacks.  For those who like to make their own coffee, this is also a great place to buy beans & grounds.  Tell them what taste you're after and they'll have a nice recommendation.
author: R S.

description: $3.75 small caramel latte & $2.00 for milk chocolate? In fact, they forgot to add the chocolate to my kids chocolate milk - WTF! dumb@sses!). Bitterly taste expresso.  Small shop which is full of coffee gear or rare/high end snacks. Whomever said this place compares to blue bottle doesn't know coffee! Initial 4 stars, minus order error, minus high price! I support small business and local business but we won't be back. btw..Friendly but not very smart employees.
author: Cee B.

description:
This place is great. It always smells so good in here, probably because they're always roasting their own beans. 

The people here are exceptionally friendly, as is the owner, Henry. He's always there, and always accessible to customers. he even replaced my coffee grinder when it cracked. Free of charge. AFTER it had been used. 

The prices are fair, the coffee is good. I have definitely been through a few of their frequent customer cards, getting my free cups.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Dear Roaster

 

    I came across your web site as I was exploring my old haunts. I used to live in San Francisco on Twin Peaks. I did my banking on Noriega Street at the Bank Of Canton and I always stopped by Your Coffee Shop to treat myself. I remember smelling the delicious scent of fresh roasting coffee. There are some pleasures in life that are unforgettable. It's been over thirty years since I've had some of your coffee and I am so looking forward to enjoying again the best coffee I've ever had!

 

     Sincerely     Dennis                   Seattle, Washington
author: Dennis M.

description:
Starbucks is to coffee what McDonald's is to burgers then the House of Coffee should be the shrine.  Okay it's appropriately cheesy.  I come here as part of my morning latte ritual before work.

One of my favorite regular coffee spots.  When I'm half asleep and desperately need my caffeine in the morning, I'm glad the staff knows what I should be ordering.  Thank you for great service.
author: Billy C.

description: I think the coffee is good..but not the greatest. sometimes the beans taste burnt but thats just me....what do i know...
author: Brendan L.

description: This is a great, local coffe shop. Staff is very friendly. Sitting area is not overcrowded like other chain establishments. No wifi, but not a big deal if you have a wireless aircard, etc. Great place to work or read for an hour or two. Free parking too!
author: Zenzo T.

description: I live in Portland where "Coffee is King" - SO, why do I order coffee beans from Henry's?  It's simple.  The beans are roasted to my liking, they provide unique blends, they ship for a reasonable fee and, instead of 12 ounces for $14 at Stumptown, Henry gives me a full 16 ounces for the same price.
author: Janice F.

description: Nice, local neighborhood coffeehouse. They have a beautiful old roaster that still works. Mmmm....love that smell. Friendly service. Yummy coffee. Seems to be the place to be in the morning.
author: Farah S.

description:
I have been going to HOF since the 70's. I read a lot of the YELP reviews but what I didn't see was anyone telling you one of the secrets of Henry and his HOF.

And that is: get a personal blend from Henry!

Not just his Henry's Blend (still my all time favorite and a fab cup of coffee!) but I mentioned one day I wanted Sumatra beans and maybe try some Kenya and Henry overheard, came out and said try this: a Sumatra, kenya and French Roast blend (1/2 lb of this, 1/3 lb of that etc. - not sure the exact blend but it is capped off with 1/4 lb or so of Fr. Roast) and it was/is one of the smoothest, most satisfying coffees I ever drank.

I told Henry he should sell it under some psuedonym (Like Henry's Blend 2?) because he said he sells a lot of it. But it is NOT on the menu, so one would never know he would make it for you (I'm talking an LB of beans, not a cup) unless you knew. He calls it KSF.

I've talked coffee with Henry for years and he knows what blends together and what doesn't. Sometimes I'll ask for a weird combo (Panama and Costa Rica for example) just to try something new but Henry will shake his head and tell you the acidity will be way too high, etc. Trust him. He came up with Henry's Blend after obviously trying many variations and it remains my #1 favorite with KSF now #2.

And for you Sunset oldtimers. I read a Chron article that indicated there was a bowling alley in the Sunset in the 70's. I moved to the Sunset in 71 but never recalled any bowling alley out there so who to ask but Henry! He recalled it and exactly where it was located. So when in doubt, I always ask Henry!
author: David R.

description:
It feels like a cozy neighborhood coffee house/store.  The staff is friendly and they seem to have quite a few regulars that they know by name.  They roast their own beans.  

For me it comes down to the coffee though and I find (1) the coffee is too bitter every single time and (2) the latte could use more foam.  A medium latte is $3.50. I've been here more than once and I'm just not a fan of their lattes.  They supply beans to Thorough Bread and Pastry and I've had their coffee there as well.

Seating is limited but they do have a few small tables.  Breakfast options are quite limited.  You'll find bagels, cookies, scones, muffins, biscotti, and Irish breakfast rolls.

They sell imported European jams, tea, and cookies (including delicious McVites digestive biscuits), alongside coffee accessories.  I bought some cookies here before (not cheap) and they had already expired, so be sure to check the date.

If you like this place, pick up a frequent buyer card.  Credit cards accepted.
author: Lolia S.

description: House of Coffee is a great place to stop by and get a cup of coffee, a bagel and smell some roasting beans.  The girls behind the counter are friendly and so is Henry.  A medium coffee costs 2.00 I believe and they have an espresso machine to make any other drinks.  Beans are for sale, though I have never bought any.
author: John B.

description:
Henry IS coffee.  It's worth the time to watch the video here - you can see how much he cares and what a great guy he is.  Besides serving wonderful coffee - he has everything for tea and coffee in his shop.   (We just bought a major espresso machine from him.)

HoC is a real find in the Sunset...always busy...try to come over when Henry is roasting.  

Henry cares about coffee, about the neighborhood and the people in it.  Get in here!
author: karen f.

description:
I love coffee. I live it and breathe it. I will drink coffee that has been sitting in the fridge since Wednesday, just to get my fix, even though I know it's awful. Hey, we can't always afford great coffee. That being said, I absolutely adore House of Coffee. 

The counter girls and Henry, who roasts the beans personally, are all very friendly and greet everyone as if they were regulars. The coffee is excellent -- you can definitely taste the difference between Henry's coffee and that of bigger coffee companies. Henry's doesn't have as much of a chemical bite and is much more aromatic. There is also a huge selection of different roasts; House of Coffee doesn't rely on artificially flavored syrups and sugars. Prices are decent, slightly cheaper than what I'm used to paying. 

There isn't a lot of seating, however, so don't expect to seat 8 people. It's more of a "pick up your coffee, weasel some candy out of Henry and go" place. 

They have a website, www.coffeesf.com, free shipping if you order 2 lbs or more! 

Experiment for those who don't believe how your roast your beans makes a difference: Boil some grounds in water, about 1:1 ratio, preferably in a glass container with a longish neck, like a pint glass. drain some water out and take a whiff. Compare.
author: Kit S.

description:
Good coffee + Neighborhood cafe = Plenty of regulars.  Staff is extremely welcoming, as they make it a point to greet and engage patrons in friendly chat.  There isn't much seating, and the endless barrage of people coming in and out (especially over the weekend) can make it a tad too noisy to work, anyway.  Instead, come here for the drinks and the service.  In addition, they sell a few coffee accessories.  They sell cartoon animal sex mugs?!?  I'll have to keep an eye out for those next time.

For those in the Sunset, it's a wonderful place to stop by for some coffee.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I have drove by this place a few times but never really acknowledged it since the shop is located between houses. 

Since I was in need of coffee this morning since I didn't have much sleep and I was on the way to the bf's house anyways I gave House of Coffee a visit. While I was finding parking I saw a fire truck parked right outside of the store. I thought wow this place MUST be good, even firemen are lining up for this! To be honest I was pretty excited to try this place haha.

I walked in and was greeted by the cutest old man ever. I believe he was the owner. He was semi-short, glasses, and had a white beard. I ordered my usual, Vanilla Soy Latte ($3.75). While I was waiting for the nice barista to finish the orders from the firemen I took a gander around the shop. They had jars of candy, tea pots, cups, CHOCOLATE!, biscottis, different varieties of coffee, and much much more. I also heard they carry Blue Mountain, one of the best tasting coffee brand out there. And no you can not find it in your everyday Safeways, Luckys, or any grocery store. At least not the ones that I've been to. 

I finally got my coffee and the taste test begins. WOW it was pretty bitter since I didn't ask for Vanilla syrup this morning for my coffee. Even though it was bitter it was good coffee. I haven't had a good cup of coffee in a while besides Tully's. I think next time I will ask for the syrup. Or maybe I should just order a cup of coffee instead of a latte.
author: Tracy A.

description: If you happen to live nearby, you will know that on some mornings, they run their industrial sized coffee roaster with their doors wide open so the smell travels a few blocks around the neighborhood. Its a great way to wake up in the morning as you step outside your door. They have all kinds of different roasts of coffee as well as a great selection of tea leaves. The barista's here are super friendly and always ready to provide a suggestion. The only reason I haven't given them 4 stars is due to Philz.
author: Rich L.

description:
GREAT coffee, friendly staff who really get to know you.  

Henry is the bomb.  I love it when he's roasting beans in te AM, smells so good.

Watch out for that street cleaning in the AM.  

Those damn guys speaking Chinese (I won't say Chinese guys) smoking outside all the time in the afternoons ruin it for me, sometimes.  I get a stomach ache when I get a whiff of cigarette smoke.  

Sometimes I come here 3-4x a day.
author: Dong T.

description:
I can't believe I haven't been here and I lived in the sunset my whole life. I know it's pathetic, but it was on my list for many many years. My drink was great, except the barista forgot that I wanted my Chai flat and left me with a foamy cup. I didn't say anything and drank it anyway but deep down that carelessness/forgetfulness of the barista annoyed me. The lattes are on the bitter side, but some people like that sort of thing. I prefer the lattes at Peet's but I have to say that House of Coffee knows coffee. 

Overall... cute place, a little expensive (almost $5 for a large latte), but worth returning because good coffee in the sunset is hard to come by.
author: Jen Y.

description:
This place is the best! My House of Coffee Vanilla Latte gets me through the day. The coffee is delicious and the people are awesome. I like to think they are my friends : ) 
The tea selection is also great!
author: Kelly B.

description:
I've never seen a coffee roaster in a coffee shop before...until House of Coffee.  Imagine that!  No wonder HoC has such amazing coffee.  I actually have a slight allergy to coffee beans, but the alluring taste of their coffee is well-worth the discomfort.  Every once in a while, I'll slap another $50-$100 on my boyfriend's tab there b/c I know we'll definitely be coming back again and again.  HoC and staff, I love you!  You've kept me awake through long boring meetings (w/o my having to resort to the coffee pods at work) and have consistently given me the energy to face the day.

Note:  This is one of those charming places that you read about in books by the fireside.  The type of people that HoC draws are a true reflection of the local community.  The interior is warm and inviting, with cute little coffee and tea knick knacks lining the walls.  To top it off, Henry is always there to greet you with a smile.
author: Kieu L.

description:
I really like this place for its non-pretentious, friendly, and the aromatic scent that you will follow the trail, almost in a cartoonish way...

People here as well as the neighborhood always give me that warm, fuzzy feeling like sitting by the fireplace on a cold night. It does not have the touristy feeling of Caffe Roma, nor the busy local Blue Bottle Cafe. Instead, you will find it on a quiet, relaxed street, perfect on a lazy afternoon when all you want is to sit back and soak in the sun and sip a cup of Joe.

They have tons of choices of coffee beans and it's best to read about them on the website to get familiar with before you go. I love the Bella Finca (blends of Indonesian, African and the third country that I don't remember) and it's quite strong-- you can see these are some very dark roasted shiny looking beans. I have also gotten Sumatra Mandheling which is also great!

You can buy them in half pound or 1-pound and I usually go for half pound and for multiple kinds. Sometimes I feel like my place is a mini-coffee shop!

They also have an amazing variety of loose tea leaves if you like the other kind of caffeine :)

Bonjour!
author: T L.

description:
Super friendly service!  Imagine real people, with real smiles.  

That toasted cheese bagel was really good.  2 bucks, worth it!  Outdoor seating, on a cool sunny Saturday... I should visit more often...

Their "smile, you're on camera" signs are fun.
author: Ethan L.

description: went in for the yelp coupon but it felt like a trap bc i was ostracized for not printing it out.  I in turn said "it's sf, we're green" he honored it but was a bit of a grump. hey, dude, i was just trying to give you business.  I was just having lunch nearby and thought that i'd give it a try since there was a discount through yelp. but now you want me to go home and print out the coupon? puh-lease. no danks
author: Emm C.

description:
Wow... I haven't been here in such a long time. Simple menu with good coffee. Really friendly staff that is quick to make your drink with little hassle and talk. 

I'd totally hang out by the table outside, but there are always old Chinese guys smoking there.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Ok, I've only been here once and I wasn't sure what to expect.  Bf and I, on our way out of town, intended to pit stop for some coffee and bagels/pastries/muffins.  As soon as you walk through the door you notice that this place is sparse.  No usual coffee house display of muffins, jars of cookies/bars.  No fresh goodies of any kind besides some packaged Irish cookies/biscuits, and two or three sorry looking saran wrapped muff fins.  I saw a hand written sign claiming that they served breakfast bagels (the aforementioned bagels were no where in sight) but I stopped reading after the mention of 'bacon bits'.  Bacon bits, as in bacos (the salad topper)???  WTF?  Anyhow, the girls working there were nice enough.  I got a large coffee, a shrink wrapped bran muffin (nasty), and a bottled oj (they only have Nantucket Nectars, which doesn't really scream good ole oj to me).

I would love to support my neighborhood coffee shop, but the lack of quality munchies kind of turns me off.  I'd rather go to Java Beach.

But, they are what they say to be, House of Coffee.  Only.  That's it.  
If they claimed to be a 'cafe' I would be more disappointed, but they are what they are, a Coffee House.
author: Emily X.

description: Stopped by here on a whim while taking my car to get a smog check.  at first, wasn't expecting much, but this place is the real deal.  they have a huge coffee selection, a few pastries/cookies to choose from and a very helpful staff.  looks like most of the patrons are regulars, as all the baristas seemed to know their names.  anyways, will definitely stop by here if Im in the neighborhood, and encourage you to check it.
author: David M.

description:
We've been getting beans ground here for almost 10 yrs.  Consistent quality coffee.  We have Blue Bottle at work, and I think House of Coffee compares well.  (House of Coffee and Blue Bottle are both gods of coffee, not to be compared to Starbucks or Tullys.  Pete's trails by a little, but not there yet.)

As for the coffee they dispense, for some reason it's not as nice as when I brew their coffee in my own kitchen, for the following reason.  When their carafe-pump-dispenser runs low, I've seen grounds in my cup - maybe they need to clean out the pump dispensers more often - which could add to the burnt bitter comments others have left.  Sometimes I tell them it's low, and they promptly swap it out for a fresh full pump dispenser, dump the contents in your cup, and start again with new dispenser . . . all is well again.

I'll continue getting our grounds here, and whenever I get a cup there, I'll continue to make sure I'm not pumping out of a very low dispenser.  Thanks, Henry!
author: Phil Y.

description: Wow, the chai tea latte that I had here was the best chai tea latte I've had. If you like cinnamon on chai tea latte, ask them to add it to the latte. Makes it taste even better. The place is a bit small and I wanted to deduct a star for that but the the quality more than makes up for it. I didn't try their regular latte or coffee but my friends who tried it said that it tasted great too. The place is far from where I work but I definitely need to plan my next visit here.
author: Govind R.

description:
Mmmm, I love waking up to the smell of some roasting coffee beans...which is every morning when you live as close to the House of Coffee as I do!  

But, as great as the coffee is, the thing that keeps me walking around the corner almost every other day is their amazing variety of loose leaf teas.  If you are a tea snob in any way, shape or form, this is the place to be.

If I'm in the mood for a caffeine and antioxidant boost, I love the Gen Mai Cha (sp?) Green tea and if I need to nix the caffeine, the rooibos red kicks ass.  

Best part is they will brew any tea for you and then pour it over ice to make it a cold beverage.

It's also pretty handy if I run out of time to make breakfast before work - they have yummy bagels and cream cheese (you can also get it with egg, cheese and bacon) as well as scones, muffins and gargantuan cookies.

Yet another Sunset neighborhood gem.
author: Sonia F.

description:
Coffee is A-1, very good. The girl behind the counter was a little sour for some reason. Maybe I caught her on a bad day. 

Hat's off to Henry tho, great coffee!
author: Brendon M.

description:
Good roasting bad costomer service. There's no argument the coffee is a phenom. The aroma and thick natural taste make it a household item especially if you're using French press. 

What really gets me though is everytime I buy coffee i need to micro-manage how they grind it. They sold me 2 useless bags on 2 different occasions because they grounded them for regular drip use not French press coarse styley.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: House of Coffee makes a GREAT white mocha composed of rich espresso pulled from their roasted-in-house espresso beans and a gentle kiss of Ghirardelli white chocolate syrup. The dusting of cinnamon for which I opted tied it all up in a bow with a label marked "Delicious." I will definitely *sip* mmmmm, be back, *sip* House of Coffee.
author: Ben D.

description:
A cute little coffee shop, and I gave it all stars because I also loved the service. I realized this morning I should come here more often, because of the "mom and pop" shop feel, friendly service, and not bad coffee. Take that again starbucks, it makes their coffee taste like poop..(sorry). 

Coffee: You can't go wrong with a place that roasts their own coffee beans. Go on in and see, you'll see the roaster! I was skeptical before visiting, but it has proven me wrong. Quality coffee. I always like to get a shot of hazelnut in my coffee. The Lattes are not bad either. Yum...I savored the coffee this morning to the last drop. 

Shop: A little cafe, not too big..but cute! Never overwhelmingly crowded, and a quiet spot to do some work or read a book. They also sell coffee goods: coffee beans, teas, candies, presses, etc.  Very clean envinronment. A few tables outside to sit too. 

Service: The best part about little shops like this is the one on one, personal service. They value customers, and the gentleman that works there is always nice. The girl at the register was very friendly as well. Always attentive, and friendly service. Love it....everyone enjoys startin their mornings off like that. 

Thanks....you rock the house..woohoo. See ya soon!
author: Catherine O.

description: Henry knows his coffee. What I always liked was the free homemade Turkish delights he gives to every customer.
author: Eric K.

description:
You can smell the coffee roasting while walking by.  
If I get a chance, I always come here.  It's a lot more expensive than other coffee shops, but it's good.  I don't know if I'd call it worth it... but the roast is def better than Starbucks.  It's like double the money compared to Peets, Tullys, and etc..I usually get an Americano, always comes out delicious.

Service is always friendly here!
author: anita h.

description: This is a very quiet small shop that sells absolutely stellar coffee.  I'm not really a coffee drinker but when I tried their regular Columbian drip coffee, you can just taste, smell, and really appreciate the high quality of their coffee.  It's very smooth andi don't think I've ever finished a cup of coffee in less than five minutes.  It's really that good.
author: Louis V.

description:
This place is a complete joke when it comes to service. I noticed a help wanted Sign hanging in their window. I asked what their application process was and they told me to simply come in and drop off a resume. I followed their instructions and returned the next day with my resume. When I tried to give it to one of the employees they told me that they would probably lose it and I should come back when the owner was in between the hours of 9:00 to 3:00.  I returned again the following day at 1:30 and the owner was not in, fortunately this time there was a different employee who took my resume and told me to call the next day. I made the phone call today to check on the status of my resume. The owner answered all I got out was " I noticed the help wanted sign and I submitted my res.."  The owner chose this time to interrupt me and say " I don't do phones I'm busy bye" and then hung up on me.
I made this call purposely during down hours at 2:30 in the afternoon. Since I live across the street I could tell they were not busy.
Incredibly rude...
I noticed his website where he tries to portray the image that he listens to customers...Ha!!!
Why would you list your phone number under contacts if you "don't do phones" Get real
author: Mark H.

description: This is a great coffee shop in the Outer Sunset! Very polite staff and quick service! Henry is always in roasting the coffee beans and it fills the place up with fresh coffee aromas!!! Best chai lattes in town hands down!
author: Michael C.

description: I happily discovered this place while waiting for my car to get examined at the Sunset 76 station around the corner. It's a pretty cozy little spot with a great selection of coffee beans. The latte was good and the warm bagel with cream cheese hit the spot. The staff was super friendly and polite and very up-beat despite it being an early morning, so props to them. If there was free wifi for patrons, I would give it 5 stars.
author: Dennis P.

description: Good coffee, friendly service....just missing, something. I don't know what. Prices were a little on the high side, so maybe I was turned off by my small $3.50 latte. No wifi, just some chairs for lounging, which is exactly what I did as I consumed the Sunday Chronicle, along with my good if overpriced small latte.
author: Jason B.

description: You can smell the coffee a mile away! This place has the best coffee in town. I must warn you it's a bit strong but so good!
author: Luna C.

description:
Growing up on Noriega, my parents have been coming here since before gourmet coffee was even something people thought about.    Henry, the owner, is a nice guy with a true passion for what he does. 

Now days, all you need to know is "Bella Finca"  This is the most delicious drip coffee I have ever had.  We go through about two pounds a week of this aromatic, beautiful coffee.  Support your local small business.
author: Mike P.

description: Great Coffee.  Sometime the girls behind the counter are awkward and there isnt much seating inside, but its great for on the go.
author: Julia G.

description: My favorite coffee shop! I love this place! The staff is great, the owner is always in there, and their chai is amazing. I am so thankful that I live just one block down but I would definitely keep coming even if I wasn't so blessed to live so close.
author: Kelly B.

description: i love this place!  very friendly owner, henry and super helpful staff.  a total gem in the sunset neighborhood!  thanks for always making me feel welcome!
author: Yan K.

description: This place totally kicks any Starbucks/Pete's/Tully's or whatever's ass. This place is so convenient. I only live two blocks away. It always smells delicious. They always remember me and they're always very friendly. It seems like they know every one's name. They remember every one's usual orders. Quite cozy. Amazing lattes.
author: MJ T.

description: Mmmmmmm coffee!  My mouth is already watering!  Just tried the Galapagos coffee and it was awesome!  The beans here always make the best french pressed coffee and that has become my weekend morning ritual.  Henry is cool and I enjoy his shop.  They sell some sick looking coffee paraphernalia!
author: Carolyn D.

description:
One of the things I enjoy about SF is all the local coffee shops. This is something I missed dearly when I was living in Amherst, MA. House of Coffee caught my eye because of the updated and pretty exterior, amongst many of the run down and drab store fronts along Noriega St. 

Let me preface this by saying I am not a coffee aficionado in anyway, despite having been put through a lame "bean school" course during my stint as a Starbucks Barista. (I know, I slummed it to put myself through college...at least I didn't wear clear heels.) I do however drink coffee every day when I have an office job.

I usually only drink drip coffee when served with breakfast, so I can't say what theirs taste like. However, I would consider buying some of their beans in the near future. I went with my "go to" drink, which is a hazelnut latte. I didn't really pay attention to price, but it was three something. About what I would expect to spend. 

The espresso was good, and the drink was not overly sweet. The service was good/average. The barista asked me if I would like any cinnamon or cocoa sprinkled on top. For the average coffee drinker, I would say that it is definitely above Starbucks, and more comparable to Peets, in terms of quality. Although it looks like other reviewers are saying it is way better than Peets. 

I liked how clean and modern the coffee shop was. There were also a few tables and chairs for sitting, and coffee, tea, etc products for purchase. I noticed they offered bagels and breakfast sandwiches, but don't expect to come here and order a fancy sandwich and salad with your coffee like some other places in SF. It is not a lunch spot.

It is nice to find a good coffee spot in the neighborhood that is not filled with bums and crackheads, or pretentious yuppies on their laptops. It seems quaint and relaxed. Somewhere locals can hang out. Although I would have to return a few times to really assess what the clientele is like. I plan on frequenting House of Coffee, and perhaps my rating will increase over time. For now, however, Coupa in Palo Alto is still my number one for coffee.
author: Marissa S.

description: As much of a coffee "store" as a coffee "shop", with coffee appliances lining the walls as well as teas, jams, and the giant, er, coffee-maker(?) in the corner (note to self: I should really learn what they call that).  The upshot: coffee connoisseurs will appreciate the serious commitment to good beans and good brewing, but there's not much in the way of food or ambiance or places to sit--you're best off sitting outside, if you're lucky enough to be here on a sunny Outer Sunset morning.  But then, a quality coffee joint is rare and welcome enough in these parts to be a ray of sunshine unto itself, especially considering it's on Noriega (truly the Harold Lloyd to Irving's Chaplin and Taraval's Keaton, for lack of a more random analogy).  I mean, aside from the Ocean Beach outposts of Java Beach Cafe and Trouble Coffee, where else are you gonna go?
author: Wes M.

description: I have searched long and hard but it is time to admit this is the best coffee in SF.
author: andrew r.

description:
I would love to rate their coffee, but didn't get a chance because of rude service.  

Waited for 15 minutes for someone to acknowledge my presence! Yap, yap, yap... counterperson yapping away with another worker.  "OMG, blah, blah, blah."  All the while, I was staring at another employee pathetically  trying to make a bagel/sandwich.  She was painfully slow.  Finally gave up and went home to make my Folgers.

Give me my Starbucks!
author: Y L.

description: This is the best coffee place on the whole street of Noriega.  One of a very few places to carry the rare and expensive Blue Mountain coffee - and for some reason, their Blue Mountain coffee is really, really good if you're willing to splurge (we're talking $100/lb easily, OK?).  There's a nice selection of tea and they stuff so many leaves into a mesh tea bag that you can go home and use that same bag and brew another huge cup.  It's a nice home-like, local coffee shop.  The roaster is right there in the shop and you can see it at work.   The staff and owner are all very nice.
author: Ry T.

description: house of coffee is so friendly, everyone is always welcoming. this shop has a good ambience and feels calm. different servers may make drinks taste slightly different from another, but i usually enjoy my cup everytime.
author: Edwin S.

description: This is our favorite coffee place that we highly recommend.  Service is good, people are friendly, atmosphere is warm and welcoming, and coffee aroma is extraordinary!
author: Liev S.

description:
Good services. Good coffee.
But latte was too hot. May be next time I need to request the temperature.
author: Keon N.

description: Fresh roasted coffee has been a long time fixture in this neighborhood thanks to House of Coffee, which also has a surprisingly good selection of loose leaf teas as well! The breakfast bagel sandwich literally had chunks of bacon (flesh) falling apart in the egg mixture........ which can be a great thing to some. The freshness of everything (including in the condiment area) will keep those in the area coming back.
author: Eugene G.

description: Pretty good coffee. I usually only order house coffee and this place had some top notch stuff. I can't vouch for any of their espresso based drinks yet. Its also always nice to see local roasted that offer a truly unique product. Thanks for existing.
author: Jonathan P.

description: My schedule, actually my daughter's schedule, takes me here often twice a week (Irish dancing).  The staff are ALWAYS friendly, patient and pleasant and the tea is a $1 for a large cup.  No surly, headphoned black garbed characters infesting the place either ... and friends say the coffee is excellent.
author: David O.

description: My husband had a great mocha here last week, so we raced here from across town to have a hot coffee. So frustrated! We got there 15 minutes before closing and the gal behind the counter informed us that they close the espresso machine down 15 minutes before closing. Although we were obviously very dissappointed she stuck to her rule and we went elsewhere for a coffee. Suggestion, post on your website house of coffee that although you say you're open till 6:00, part of your product is only available till 5:45. Bad experience!
author: Myra H.

description:
If you like chewing on a mouth full of coffee grounds then this is your place.   I had finished 3/4 of my coffee when all of a sudden I had a mouth full of grounds.  I opened my cup and there were so many grounds in the bottom of the cup it looked like mud.  Since this place only serves coffee from decanter I thought I would tell the owner.  I walked up to him and said just an FYI, showed him the inside of my cup and said that if I have this many grounds in my coffee then the people being served after me are getting grounds too.  The response just floored me.  He said it is common for the first few cups poured from a new pot to have grounds and looked at me like I should have known that.   I did not want anything for bringing this to his attention but just the offer to get me a fresh cup, or him having someone at least check the decanter the coffee was being served from would have sufficed.  I only wanted to prevent others from getting a mouth full of grounds but oh my, I didn't realize that this was part of their coffee experience.

I have only been here a couple of times and I must say there are some good things (nice selection of ground coffee) as well as bad about this shop but I am sorry, if you expect customers to eat grounds with their coffee then I'll just head to one of the other coffee shops in the sunset district.

Just my humble two-bit opinion.
author: R H.

description:
The House of Coffee makes some of the best coffee in SF.

I have been to Blue Bottle, Caffe Trieste, Ritual Roasters, Peets and let me tell you the best coffee is at the House of Coffee.

Henry, the owner, and the rest of the staff are very friendly.  In the 8 years I have been going here I have never had rude service.  If you ask Henry about anything coffee he is always more than willing to explain coffee preparations, roasting techniques or anything else coffee.  Once he told me that if I were to setup a time with him he would brew a couple of different blends to show different coffee flavors, unfortunately I didn't take him up on his offer.

I will agree with others, it not a normal coffee shop it is more of a roaster.  If you want a starbucks type shop with loads of pastries, where you can sit down and connect to the wireless, this is not the place.  The House of Coffee specializes in roasting coffee.

If you pick up a pound I highly recommend the Panama La Torcaza.
As Henry said to me once, "Nothing is smoother than the Panama".
author: spazzy p.

description: I went in at exactly 5:30 and they were out of drip coffee and had already shut down their espresso machine even though they close at 6.  Huge disappointment since I've wanted to try them out for some time.  Not so sure I'm willing to try my luck again.
author: Heather C.

description: After reading the reviews below, I thought this place would be amazing but it was just good. I was expecting more variety in the menu but they just had the basics like lattes, cafe au laits, espressos, etc. Perhaps their thought is that simple is better. I guess I'm into places that have signature drinks and I didn't see any here. I'm totally spoiled by the Kean Coffee in Newport Beach. I got a latte with a pump of cinnamon syrup and it was pretty yummy. My friend got a soy mocha and it tasted like hot cocoa. It was good but I like the taste of coffee and the mocha lacked that. There are only 3 little round tables so it's not exactly the kind of place you sit and chill for a while. The girl taking my order was really friendly. If I lived in SF I would come back, but I would definitely try other places before and if that happens.
author: Linda Y.

description: Yeah, I know, it's only coffee, but its good coffee, and I think that staff is so friendly magical, that they make the coffee better... I will be back, oh yes, I will.
author: danny e.

description:
early hours, limited menu, sparse seating. and i'm not much of a coffee guy. but the ladies that work here are the main appeal. 

annette, darcy, julianne and co are the friendliest baristas i've ever encountered. come in just for the guaranteed quirky [and sometimes awkward] conversation and sweeter than sweet powdered chai lattes. it's a house of coffee must.
author: Emmanuel A.

description:
Maybe the best coffee in California.  I am from Seattle and quite picky.  It is refreshing to be able to walk in and talk about blends with the proprietor Henry.  Not only is he a wealth of knowledge, but he is a purist as well.  Other 'fast-food' type coffee joints just toss beans together with no sense, and call it a 'new blend.'  To me this is as revolting as mixing a chardonay and cab to get a 'new wine.'  

Try House of Coffee, talk to Henry...it's like a trip back in time to the old world.

ps - just ordered several Christmas presents via their website, www.coffeesf.com 

Very good looking website, and easy to use.  So much better than other coffee-sites that try to be 'everything.'
author: Jason S.

description: Best place in the city to get coffee! I always try my best to get my coffee from here during the weekends since its impossible to make it out there during the week! The staff is really friendly, esp the irish cashier who is always talking it up with the regulars! I usually don't like to drink mochas because they're too sweet, but this place makes it perfect! Just a dab of chocolate and all the fabulous coffee flavor.
author: Angela T.

description: This is a nice spot to grab a no fuss coffee or espresso drink in the sunset.  The neighborhood is lousy for parking but if you are a local like me its a nice spot to walk to on Noriega.  If you are looking for a high end coffee shop this is not your spot but the coffee is good and hot and essential in my opinion.
author: Halima T.

description:
since it's only a block down from my live....it was one of the reasons why i started coming here...it must be over five years now since i switched from my normal starbucks routine to house of coffee...Henry whose' the master roaster you can see him greet all his regulars by name...always courteous.....you'll see him turn on the coffee roaster and go ahhhh they don't have that at starbucks or peets......price is a bit more but you get what you pay for...all the ladies that work there....are very friendly and take pride in making coffee just right....for me it's worth the $5.00 for my tripple hazlenut latte or white mocha....it's just awesome...and you'll be "wired" all day....!!!

cheers enjoy it...!!! 

just watch out for the meter maids on Monday's and Tuesday's...!!!

Bobby =)
author: Bobby K.

description: Some of the best whole bean coffee around in my opinion. If you like to grind your java at home before you brew, House of Coffee is a must try. Granted their prices aren't exactly cheap but if you are as serious about your coffee as you are about getting your pick-me-up in the morning, then you should give them a shot.
author: Stephanie I.

description: (really 3.5 stars) I like the idea this place does it all on their own, but the coffee is only as good as other coffee in the city (starbucks excluded, which sucks).  They would get more stars if they had a better selection of pastries to go with the coffee.
author: p w.

description: My favorite roaster in SF. I really like the kona hawaii ground for a press. Usually with an irish breakfast sandwich with an egg and HP sauce!
author: Gus H.

description: Very simple coffee house, no bells or whistles, just good home roasted coffee.
author: Phil M.

description: This place roasts their own coffee, the staff is really friendly, and they offer brown sugar in the condiment bar. It doesn't take much more to make me happy, but THEN, I discovered they sell ceramic coffee mugs with cute cartoon animals having sex. I was compelled to buy one.
author: Netty L.

description: Only the best place to grab a cup of coffee in San Francisco!  Ok, maybe just south of Golden Gate Park :P  It's a quaint little mom & pop coffee house right smack in the middle of Sunset.   It's a nice change from Starbucks.
author: Christina L.

description: I came here because I was waiting for laundry to finish washing at the end of the street. When I came in, I saw all the biscuits and snacks I normally have in Germany, and I became nostalgic. While their drinks are a higher price than that of your chain shops (ie Starbucks), they are much more a friendlier place. They even know your name if you're a regular! Well I guess some Starbucks locations do the same, but I think they only do that to attempt recreating the individualistic feeling that usually comes from coffee shops such as this.  I'm not too big on coffee so I had hot chocolate, but boy this hot chocolate was much better and did not have that weird taste like the Starbucks one. It did take a little bit longer to prepare the drink, but I think that is much better than having a pre-made package prepared for you in 30 seconds.
author: Yosie G.

description: stumbled across this cafe and roaster today- I went in and had a really nice shot of espresso and wound up getting a half pound of beans to go to pull a shot at home later. really nice staff too.
author: El T.

description: Great place!  Nice to have a real coffee shop out here in the outer sunset. The coffee is great and folks that work here are super. You can get a real good egg on bagel sandwich too.  Nice collection of teas, treats and coffee paraphenalia also.
author: James C.

description: Locals rave about blue bottle and philz, but I really believe house of coffee had the best coffee. I have never been dissapointed with a cup of coffee from there and I always stop buy to pick up a lb of freshly roasted beans.
author: Paige B.

description: I love this place.  Always helpful, friendly service, and a damn good cup of coffee.  Great "accessories" too.
